You said you are drinking enough water to drown a whale . . . are you craving water and urinating frequently?Reason I'm asking is many thyroid patients also have problems with blood glucose (diabetes or hypoglycemia).  Here are the most frequent warning signs of Type II diabetes:Increased thirst.Increased hunger (especially after eating).Dry mouth.Frequent urination.Recent weight gain.Fatigue (weak, tired feeling.Blurred vision.Headaches.Loss of consciousness (rare).Less frequent symptoms:Slow-healing sores or cuts.Itching of the skin (usually around the vaginal or groin area).Frequent yeast infections.Numbness and tingling of the hands and feet.Decreased vision.Impotency.Since thyroid conditions and diabetes (Type II usually) often go hand-in-hand, please contact your doctor to be tested if you are experiencing these symptoms.  Diabetes is a very silent disease and needs to be controlled at the earliest possible stages before serious damage can occur.I know that in the past six weeks, after being on the very restrictive LID diet and going through the holidays, I haven't been good at controlling my carb intake and my blood sugar has been a bit high at times.  Needless to say I've put on 8lbs in six weeks, just from not managing the carbs.  Darn those oatmeal raisin cookies!!!  And I'm only classified as "pre-diabetic" but my glucose levels can get into the mid 200s without any effort.Please call your doctor and/or invest in a home glucose meter.  Oh, and welcome to the "I've got a messed up endocrine system" club!  :-)

It has been documented that patients starting on thyroid med often find that their levels decline slightly or stay the same until the dosage is gradually raised enough to move the levels of Free T4 and Free T3.  So patients starting on thyroid med frequently think that the med is causing the problem, when the real cause is that the levels of Free T4 and Free T3 are still to low in the range.  So, please post your thyroid related test results from before and after starting on the thyroid med, along with their reference ranges shown on the lab report, so that we can assess your status.  Also, do you have any other symptoms?
